sentences.sentence: Clashing assessments of the city's approach.

Also: Donald Trump's threat on social media; a Republican climate plan; children of elite soccer moms.To the Editor:“Mayor Adams Turns His Back on Immigrants and His City's Legacy,” by Mara Gay (Opinion, Aug. 4), is deeply offensive to thousands of New York City public servants who are almost single-handedly managing an international crisis.In the span of a year, our shelter population has more than doubled.

We've manufactured space for more than95,000 asylum seekers, opened194 sites, welcomed thousands ofstudents into schools, helped submit more than1,300 asylum applicationsand partnered withhundreds of nonprofits.
We will spendbillions on this crisis.We've done all this while Monday-morning quarterbacks like Ms.
Gay ask why we aren't doing more, without a mention of work authorization, which is what asylum seekers ask for most of all.We find Ms.
Gay's comparison of Mayor Adams to Gov.
Greg Abbott of Texas and Gov.
Ron DeSantis of Florida wildly off-base, not to mention insulting.
Mayor Adams leads an administration that has cared for 95,000 asylum seekers.
Governors Abbott and DeSantis trafficked migrants to the Northeast.
These two approaches are plainly not the same.We're doing everything we can, and we've figured out how to do plenty of things that seemed impossible, too.The real question is: Why is Ms.

Gay attacking the administration that is leading the nation in handling this crisis, instead of focusing on the need for more comprehensive federal and state action on an issue that clearly transcends the jurisdiction or capacity of any one city?Camille Joseph VarlackIngrid P. Lewis-MartinSheena WrightNew YorkThe writers are, respectively, chief of staff to Mayor Eric Adams, chief adviser and first deputy mayor.To the Editor:Kudos to Mara Gay.
Indeed, this city should be welcoming immigrants and asylum seekers with every resource we have.

Not only is it the right thing to do, but history and current economists tell us it will profit the city immensely.In fact, several of our employment sectors ᅳ construction, restaurant and food service, and home health care ᅳ are in need of new entry-level workers and could train this population into jobs that would allow them to become financially independent.Not only is the administration response too limited and divisive, but it also ignores and frustrates the amazing response of individuals and organizations that have built and staffed a thrift shop, opened welcome desks in houses of worship, and stepped forward with everything from shoes to legal aid to health information to English classes.The outpouring of care is huge and would be larger if groups were not constantly ignored, frustrated or denied access to shelters and hotels.

Partnerships with these groups could ease the burden on the city and enhance the welcome from a city of immigrants to our newest New Yorkers.Ruth W. MessingerNew YorkThe writer, a social justice consultant and an immigrant center volunteer, was the Manhattan borough president from 1990 to 1997 and the Democratic nominee for mayor of New York in 1997.Trump's Threatening Post on Social MediaTo the Editor:Re “Prosecutors Seek Protective Order Over Evidence” (news article, Aug. 6):Donald Trump was specifically directed at his arraignment not to attempt to threaten or intimidate witnesses.

He has had similar directives by judges in his other pending cases not to use threatening incendiary language.So he posts in capital letters shortly after the last hearing “IF YOU GO AFTER ME, I'M COMING AFTER YOU!” ᅳ a clear threat to judges, prosecutors, witnesses and possible jurors.Experienced federal prosecutors have stated that if any other defendant so blatantly violated court orders, they would likely be sent to jail to await trial.At the very least there should be an immediate hearing and a clear unmistakable message that one more violation and he'll be sent to jail.

I am so tired of Donald Trump flouting the rules and getting away with it.Richard GoetzDelray Beach, Fla.To the Editor:Jurors are asked carefully to examine the evidence presented in a trial, in accordance with a judge's instructions.

Donald Trump has already lashed out at prosecutors, judges and potential witnesses and has exhorted his followers to take action.Unless jurors (and any family members) are guaranteed protection or anonymity during and after any trial, who would be able to exercise the needed care to serve as a juror in any of the upcoming trials of Mr. Trump?David AustinPittsburghA 'Dangerous' Republican Climate PlanTo the Editor:Re “G.O.P.

Blueprint for '25: Gutting Climate Progress” (front page, Aug. 5):It is hard to fathom just how irresponsible, wrongheaded, nihilistic and radical the Republican Party's Project 2025 is.It is bad enough that these Republican so-called leaders deny the science of climate change, which scientists agree on virtually unanimously, but they also plan to roll back federal efforts to respond to this crisis.
These people are dangerous beyond belief.We cannot let them be put in positions of power.

They must be stopped, for the sake of human civilization on this fragile, exquisite small planet.Paul HarperMinneapolisTo the Editor:First, Republicans sidetracked meaningful gun legislation, then they made their anti-abortion stance a central and losing strategy in the 2022 midterm elections, and now they have given voters yet another reason to shun them at the polls in 2024.While the former president takes up most of the print ink and television coverage, the threat of continuing global climate change stands alone as the most pressing issue of our time.It is a real head scratcher to me that the Republican Party is making a decision to gut climate policy in the midst of the most drastic heat waves menacing populations around the globe, but nothing seems to stand in the way of the Republicans shooting themselves in the foot once again.Democrats should be taking to the airwaves immediately to denounce this idiotic and critically ill-timed policy decision.Henry A. LowensteinNewport, R.I.Children of Elite Soccer MomsTo the Editor:Re “In Elite Soccer, Risking Career to Be a Mother” (front page, Aug. 1):I noticed much hand-wringing in the comments about the potential negative effects on children of having mothers whose attention is sometimes divided between them and careers as elite athletes.What's missing from that analysis is the incredible benefits to children of growing up traveling the world, seeing their mothers achieve greatness and being cared for not only by mothers and fathers, but also by extended families and caring teammates.We should welcome the presence of children and seek to create supportive, caring communities for them in all professions.Emily HoppeBaltimoreThis article appeared in print on page A21.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

Also: Donald Trump’s threat on social media; a Republican climate plan; children of elite soccer moms.To the Editor:“Mayor Adams Turns His Back on Immigrants and His City’s Legacy,” by Mara Gay (Opinion, Aug. 4), is deeply offensive to thousands of New York City public servants who are almost single-handedly managing an international crisis.In the span of a year, our shelter population has more than doubled.
